summary: This document is an email exchange between two FBI personnel, likely a supervisor and a subordinate, discussing the supervisor's departure. The subordinate thanks the supervisor for the opportunity to work on the VCAC (Violent Crimes Against Children) squad and for being a strong advocate for victims, specifically referencing the Epstein case. The supervisor responds with encouragement to continue fighting for victims.

persons.name: Unknown Supervisor
persons.context: The recipient of a farewell email, described as a strong advocate for victims and a boss who supported the VCAC squad's work on the Epstein case. They are departing for the next step in their career.

persons.name: Unknown Subordinate
persons.context: The author of the initial farewell email, thanking their supervisor for the opportunity to work on the VCAC squad and for their advocacy for victims, specifically mentioning the Epstein case.

connections.description: Subordinate agent expressing gratitude to their departing supervisor for career opportunities and leadership, specifically on the VCAC squad and Epstein case.

events.title: Supervisor Career Transition
events.description: An FBI supervisor is departing for the next step in their career, prompting a farewell email exchange with a subordinate.

keyFacts: The email exchange involves FBI personnel from the VCAC (Violent Crimes Against Children) squad discussing the Epstein case.
The supervisor is praised as a 'strong advocate for victims' who aimed for their best interest.
The subordinate acknowledges being asked to do a lot of work on the Epstein case, indicating active FBI investigation and workload.
The correspondence highlights internal FBI support and focus on victim advocacy in cases like Epstein's.
